facts.text: Writ Petition No. 274 of 1971 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 274 of 1971. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat,J.

facts.text: Order of detention dated April 7, 1971 passed against the petitioner under sections 3(1) and 3 of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, President's Act 19 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention,dated April 7, 1971, passed against the petitioner herein and in pursuance of which the petitioner was arrested and detained in jail the next day, recites that it was passed under sec. 3 1  and  3  of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, Presidents Act 19 of 1970

facts.text: District Magistrate, 24 Parganas passed the detention order, satisfied it was necessary to detain petitioner to prevent acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: , the ground for which was that the District Magistrate, 24 Parganas, who passed it, was satisfied that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested and detained in jail on April 8, 1971 pursuant to detention order.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention,dated April 7, 1971, passed against the petitioner herein and in pursuance of which the petitioner was arrested and detained in jail the next day

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner at time of arrest narrated three incidents.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention served on him at the time of his arrest narrated three incidents in which he was said to have been involved.

facts.text: On November 13, 1970, petitioner with others committed theft of copper traction wire from wagon in Naihati South Yard and threw bombs at railway police and protection force.

anchor.surface_text: The first ground was that on November 13, 1970 he, together with some others, companymitted theft of companyper traction wire from a wagon lying in Naihati South Yard, and that when the railway police and the railway protection force on duty rushed at the spot, the petitioner and his associates threw bombs at them with intent to kill them.

facts.text: On December 23, 1970, petitioner and associates removing 29 pieces of rail from Naihati South Yard and threw bombs at railway protection force.

anchor.surface_text: The second ground was that on December 23, 1970, the petitioner and his associates were removing 29 pieces of rail from the same railway yard and when the members of the railway protection force attempted to stop them from doing so, the petitioner and his said associates threw bombs at them with intent to kill them.

facts.text: On January 13, 1971 between 12:00 and 12:20 hours, petitioner with associates armed with bombs, swords, lathis entered clash with another group, creating panic in station area.

anchor.surface_text: The third and the last ground was as follows That on 13-1-71 in between 12.00 and 12.20, hours, you along with your associates being armed with bombs, swords, lathis, etc. entered in a clash with, another group with a view to kill them. Your violent activities created a serious panic in the station area and disturbed the public order.

facts.text: Petitioner detained in Dum Dum Central Jail.

anchor.surface_text: From the Dum Dum Central Jail where the petitioner was detained he made a representation

facts.text: Petitioner made representation dated April 29, 1971 to State Government denying grounds and claiming to be law abiding citizen.

anchor.surface_text: From the Dum Dum Central Jail where the petitioner was detained he made a representation, dated April 29, 1971, to the State Government. That representation together with the record of the case was placed before the Advisory Board, who it appears, also heard the petitioner in person. The representation, dated April 29, 1971 was in general terms in which the petitioner denied the said grounds alleged against him, and maintained that he was a law abiding citizen who never indulged in activities of the kind alleged against him.

facts.text: Representation and record placed before Advisory Board, who heard petitioner in person.

anchor.surface_text: That representation together with the record of the case was placed before the Advisory Board, who it appears, also heard the petitioner in person.

facts.text: Advisory Board reported sufficient cause for detention after considering representation, record and hearing petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, after companysidering the said representation, the said record of the case and after hearing him, as aforesaid, reported that there was, in its opinion, sufficient cause for his detention.

facts.text: Government confirmed detention order and directed continuation of detention.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that thereupon the Government companyfirmed the said detention order and directed companytinuation of his detention thereunder.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested in Naihati G.R.P. Case No. 11 dated November 23, 1970 under sections 148, 379, 307 IPC and section 6 of Explosive Substances Act, released on bail by Magistrate Sealdah, case pending.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners allegation was that on January 1, 1971 the Naihati G.R.P. police appeared before, the Magistrate, Sealdah, stating that the petitioner was arrested in a police case referred to as Naihati G.R.P. Case No. 11, dated November 23, 1970 under sees. 148, 379 and 307 of the Penal Code and sec. 6 3  of the Explosive Substances Act, but that the Magistrate, after companysidering the facts and circumstances of the case, released him on bail. That case, according to the petitioner was still pending.

facts.text: Petitioner denied involvement in all three grounds in representation and written arguments.

anchor.surface_text: The representation, dated April 29, 1971 was in general terms in which the petitioner denied the said grounds alleged against him... In his written arguments submitted to this Court he, firstly, denied having anything to do with the incident of January 13, 1971

facts.text: Petitioner claimed no case filed for January 13, 1971 incident, indicating false involvement.

anchor.surface_text: in the written arguments submitted by the petitioner from jail, the petitioner made a general denial stating that, if such an incident had occurred and he had been involved in it the police were bound to file a case against him but that numbersuch case was filed which indicated that he had numberhing to do with the alleged incident

facts.text: Ground No. 3 vague as it does not specify station area or the other group.

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 3, numberdoubt, specifies the date and the time when the incident alleged therein was said to have taken place. It also alleges that the petitioner and his associates were armed during the alleged incident with weapons such as bombs, swords, lathis etc., and that they had a clash with another group, and that incident created a serious panic in the station area. The ground does number state what the authority meant by another group, number does it state in which station area the said alleged incident was said to have taken place resulting in panic.

facts.text: Petitioner under impression that January 13 incident was in Naihati railway station area due to context of other grounds.

anchor.surface_text: It is, thus, clear that the petitioner was under the impression, in the absence, of the place or the locality where the said incident was said to have taken place, according to the District Magistrate, either in Naihati railway Station or the area under the jurisdiction of Naihati police station.

facts.text: In affidavit in reply, State averred January 13, 1971 incident took place at Palta Railway Station, not Naihati.

anchor.surface_text: In Para 7 of the affidavit in reply of the State, the averment for the first time made was that the alleged incident of January 13, 1971 took place number in Naihati Railway Station area but at Palta Railway Station which resulted in panic in the said station area and disturbed public peace and tranquility.

facts.text: Court held ground No. 3 vague, preventing effective representation, detention invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result of those omissions being to prevent the petitioner from effectively making representation, his detention under the said order must be found to be invalid. The petition, for the reasons aforesaid. succeeds and is allowed. Accordingly we direct that the petitioner be released from jail and set at liberty forthwith.

facts.text: Court directs petitioner's release from jail forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, for the reasons aforesaid. succeeds and is allowed. Accordingly we direct that the petitioner be released from jail and set at liberty forthwith.

concepts.interpretation: Grounds of detention must contain specific particulars such as place and identity of opposing group to enable detenu to make effective representation; vagueness invalidates detention

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibition against parallel criminal and preventive detention proceedings

anchor.surface_text: the authorities, having elected to institute proceedings against him under the Code of Criminal Procedure, companyld number, while those proceedings were still pending, also take parallel proceedings under the present Act

issues.text: Whether the detaining authorities could initiate preventive detention proceedings under the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act while criminal proceedings under sections 148, 379, 307 IPC and section 6 Explosive Substances Act were pending, thereby placing the petitioner under double jeopardy and conducting investigation without court's supervision and control?

anchor.surface_text: The point raised by the petitioner was in regard to ground No. 2 in the grounds of detention in which it was alleged that the petitioner participated in the incident said to have taken place on December 23, 1970. The petitioners allegation was that on January 1, 1971 the Naihati G.R.P. police appeared before, the Magistrate, Sealdah, stating that the petitioner was arrested in a police case referred to as Naihati G.R.P. Case No. 11, dated November 23, 1970 under sees. 148, 379 and 307 of the Penal Code and sec. 6 3  of the Explosive Substances Act,

issues.text: Whether ground No. 3 of the grounds of detention is vague and couched in indefinite language lacking particulars of the place (station area) and the identity of 'another group', thereby preventing the petitioner from effectively making a representation?

anchor.surface_text: The second contention concerned the third ground of the grounds of detention and related to the alleged incident, dated January 13, 1971, when the petitioner and his associates who were armed with bombs, swords, lathis etc. were said to have clashed with another group. In the written arguments submitted by the petitioner from jail, the petitioner made a general denial stating that, if such an incident had occurred and he had been involved in it the police were bound to file a case against him but that nosuch case was filed which indicated that he had nothing to do with the alleged incident, and had been falsely involved in it. Counsel appearing for him raised another point, and that was that ground No. 3 was vague and uncertain and was couched in such indefinite language that it would be impossible for the petitioner to effectively make a representation.

arguments.claim: Authorities having elected to institute criminal proceedings under CrPC could not take parallel preventive detention proceedings while criminal case pending, placing petitioner under double jeopardy and conducting investigation without court's supervision and control; detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: The contention was that the authorities, having elected to institute proceedings against him under the Code of Criminal Procedure, could not, while those proceedings were still pending, also take parallel proceedings under the present Act thereby placing, firstly, the petitioner under a double jeopardy, and secondly, conducting investigation in that case without that courts supervision and control.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as petition succeeds on ground 3 vagueness

arguments.claim: Ground No. 3 vague and uncertain, couched in indefinite language lacking particulars of place and another group, making effective representation impossible

arguments.claim: Incident of January 13, 1971 took place not in Naihati Railway Station area but at Palta Railway Station, resulting in panic there

anchor.surface_text: In Para 7 of the affidavit in reply of the State, the averment for the first time made was that the alleged incident of January 13, 1971 took place not in Naihati Railway Station area but at Palta Railway Station which resulted in panic in the said station area

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anytext of the first and the second grounds, the reader of the third ground in the absence of any particulars as regards the -L887 Sup Cl/72 locality

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted as fact but used to highlight vagueness since not in grounds

arguments.claim: Ground No. 3 vague due to omission of locality (Palta not mentioned, context suggested Naihati) and identity of another group, preventing petitioner from making effective representation; detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 3, nodoubt, specifies the date and the time when the incident alleged therein was said to have taken place. It also alleges that the petitioner and his associates were armed during the alleged incident with weapons such as bombs, swords, lathis etc., and that they had a clash with another group, and that incident created a serious panic in the station area.

arguments.claim: Petitioner denied all three grounds of detention and asserted he is a law abiding citizen never indulging in such activities

anchor.surface_text: The representation, dated April 29, 1971 was in general terms in which the petitioner denied the said grounds alleged against him, and maintained that he was a law abiding citizen who never indulged in activities of the kind alleged against him.

holdings.text: Ground No. 3 is vague by reason of its omission to mention the locality where the incident took place and the identity of 'another group', and in the context of the other two grounds created a likelihood of wrong impression as to the place (Naihati instead of Palta), preventing the petitioner from effectively making a representation.

anchor.surface_text: Apart, thus, from ground No. 3 in the grounds of detention being vague by reason of its omission to mention the locality, there was in the context of the other two grounds a likelihood of the petitioner, being under a wrong impression that according to .he District Magistrate the incident there alleged had taken place in Naihati Railway Station area. That being so, it is obvious that the petitioner could not make a correct and proper represen- tation which must mean that the omission to mention the locality prevented him from effectively making a representation. The omission to specify the group with whom the petitioner and his associates came into clash also renders that ground vague and indefinite, resulting once again in disabling the petitioner from effectively making a representation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ground lacks particulars of place and opposing group; contextual reading with prior grounds misled petitioner on location (Naihati vs Palta as clarified in reply affidavit); this disabled proper defense or representation as required under natural justice.

holdings.text: The result of those omissions being to prevent the petitioner from effectively making representation, his detention under the said order must be found to be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result of those omissions being to prevent the petitioner from effectively making representation, his detention under the said order must be found to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vagueness in one ground violates constitutional right to make effective representation against detention (Art 22(5) implied), rendering entire detention order invalid as severability not applicable.

holdings.text: The petition succeeds and is allowed. Accordingly we direct that the petitioner be released from jail and set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, for the reasons aforesaid. succeeds and is allowed. Accordingly we direct that the petitioner be released from jail and set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on invalidity of detention order due to defective grounds.
